cards.front: How do you calculate the mean (average)?
cards.back: Sum of all values divided by number of values: (x₁ + x₂ + ... + xn) / n

cards.front: How do you find the median?
cards.back: Sort the data, median is the middle value. For even count, average of two middle values.

cards.front: What is the mode?
cards.back: The value that appears most frequently in a dataset.

cards.front: How do you calculate variance?
cards.back: Average of squared differences from the mean: Σ(xi - μ)² / n

cards.front: What is standard deviation?
cards.back: Square root of variance, measures spread of data around the mean.

cards.front: What does a correlation coefficient of -1 mean?
cards.back: Perfect negative correlation - as one variable increases, the other decreases.

cards.front: What does a p-value less than 0.05 indicate?
cards.back: Statistically significant result - the observed effect is unlikely due to chance.

cards.front: What is a 95% confidence interval?
cards.back: Range where we are 95% confident the true population parameter lies.

title: Pandas Data Manipulation
description: Common pandas operations for data analysis.

cards.front: How do you read a CSV file in pandas?
cards.back:
import pandas as pd
df = pd.read_csv('file.csv')

cards.front: How do you view the first 5 rows of a DataFrame?
cards.back: df.head()

cards.front: How do you get DataFrame information?
cards.back: df.info() - shows columns, dtypes, non-null counts

cards.front: How do you get summary statistics?
cards.back: df.describe() - shows count, mean, std, min, quartiles, max

cards.front: How do you filter rows in pandas?
cards.back:
df[df['column'] > value]
df.query('column > value')

cards.front: How do you group data and aggregate?
cards.back: df.groupby('category')['value'].mean()

cards.front: How do you join two DataFrames?
cards.back: pd.merge(df1, df2, on='key', how='inner')

cards.front: How do you handle missing values?
cards.back:
df.fillna(value) - fill with specific value
df.dropna() - remove rows with NaN

title: Machine Learning Concepts
description: Key ML algorithms and evaluation metrics.

cards.front: Difference between supervised and unsupervised learning?
cards.back:
Supervised: labeled training data, predict outputs
Unsupervised: unlabeled data, find patterns/structures

cards.front: When to use linear regression?
cards.back: Predict continuous numerical values with linear relationship between variables.

cards.front: When to use logistic regression?
cards.back: Binary classification problems, outputs probability between 0 and 1.

cards.front: Advantages of decision trees?
cards.back: Easy to interpret, handle both numerical and categorical data, no need for scaling.

cards.front: What is Random Forest?
cards.back: Ensemble method combining multiple decision trees to reduce overfitting and improve accuracy.

cards.front: How does K-Means clustering work?
cards.back: Iteratively assigns points to K clusters based on distance to centroids, then updates centroids.

cards.front: Why use cross-validation?
cards.back: Provides more reliable performance estimates, helps detect overfitting, makes better use of limited data.

cards.front: How to determine feature importance?
cards.back: Random Forest feature_importances_, correlation analysis, recursive feature elimination, permutation importance.

title: Data Visualization
description: Creating effective visualizations with Python libraries.

cards.front: Basic matplotlib line plot?
cards.back:
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt
plt.plot(x, y)
plt.xlabel('X Label')
plt.ylabel('Y Label')
plt.title('Title')
plt.show()

cards.front: Seaborn scatter plot with hue?
cards.back:
import seaborn as sns
sns.scatterplot(data=df, x='x_col', y='y_col', hue='category')

cards.front: When to use a histogram?
cards.back: Show distribution of a single continuous variable, visualize data spread and central tendency.

cards.front: What does a box plot show?
cards.back: Median, quartiles, outliers, and spread of data distribution.

cards.front: How to create a correlation heatmap?
cards.back:
import seaborn as sns
corr_matrix = df.corr()
sns.heatmap(corr_matrix, annot=True, cmap='coolwarm')

cards.front: How to create multiple plots in one figure?
cards.back:
fig, axes = plt.subplots(2, 2)
axes[0,0].plot(x1, y1)
axes[0,1].scatter(x2, y2)

cards.front: Why use Plotly for visualization?
cards.back: Creates interactive plots, supports web deployment, better for exploratory data analysis.

cards.front: Data visualization best practices?
cards.back: Choose appropriate chart types, use clear labels, avoid chart junk, ensure color accessibility, tell a story with data.
